{{Infobox musical artist | name = Shakey Jake Harris | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = James D. Harris | alias = Shakey Jake | birth_date = {{birth date|1921|4|12|mf=y}}
[[Earle, Arkansas|Earle]], [[Arkansas]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|1990|3|2|1921|4|12|mf=y}}
[[Forrest City, Arkansas]], United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]], [[harmonica]] | genre = [[Chicago blues]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[List of harmonicists|harmonicist]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = Late 1940s–late 1980s | label = [[Cobra Records|Artistic]], [[Bluesville Records|Bluesville]], [[Pacific Jazz Records|World Pacific]] | associated_acts = [[Magic Sam]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Shakey Jake Harris''' (April 12, 1921 – March 2, 1990){{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1990.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1990 - 1991 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] [[singing|singer]], [[List of harmonicists|harmonicist]] and [[songwriter]]. Harris released five albums over a period of almost 25 years, and he was often musically associated with his nephew, [[Magic Sam]]. ==Biography== '''James D. Harris''' was born in [[Earle, Arkansas|Earle]], [[Arkansas]], but relocated with his family to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], at the age of seven. He played in several Chicago blues [[musical ensemble|ensembles]] in the late 1940s. He also worked as a mechanic, and a professional gambler (from whence his [[nickname]] came - "Shake 'em").{{cite book | first= Gérard | last= Herzhaft | year= 1997 | title= Encyclopedia of the Blues | edition= 2nd | publisher= The University of Arkansas Press | location= Fayetteville | isbn= 1-55728-452-0 | page= 184}} His debut [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] did not take place until 1958. His [[single (music)|single]], "Call Me If You Need Me" / "Roll Your Moneymaker", was released by [[Cobra Records|Artistic Records]], featured [[Magic Sam]] and [[Syl Johnson]] on guitar, and was [[record producer|produced]] by [[Willie Dixon]].{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/shakey-jake-harris-mn0001212808/biography |title=Shakey Jake Harris | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}}[http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/musician.php?id=7459 ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}} Harris was not paid for the session, but won $700 shooting [[craps]] with label owner Eli Toscano.Rowe, M (1981). ''Chicago Blues: the city and the music'', New York: Da Capo Press, p. 180 In 1960, [[Bluesville Records]] teamed Harris with the [[jazz]] [[musician]]s [[Jack McDuff]] and Bill Jennings, for the [[album]] ''Good Times''. His later recording of ''Mouth Harp Blues'' returned to more traditional blues ground. Harris toured, and was part of the [[American Folk Blues Festival]] in 1962. Throughout the 1960s Harris and Sam appeared regularly in concert together around Chicago, and Harris's patronage of younger musicians helped secure [[Luther Allison]]'s recording debut. Harris moved on in the late 1960s, and recorded with Allison in [[Los Angeles]] on ''Further on Up the Road''. He also played with other harmonica players, such as [[William Clarke (musician)|William Clarke]].{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | isbn= 1-85868-255-X | page= 101}} Harris subsequently recorded for [[Pacific Jazz Records|World Pacific]]. He also owned his own [[nightclub]] and a [[record label]], but was forced by ill health to eventually return to Arkansas, where he died, at the age of 68, in March 1990. ==Selected discography== ===Singles=== *"Call Me If You Need Me"/"Roll Your Moneymaker" (1958) - Artistic *"Respect Me Baby"/"A Hard Road" (1966) - The BluesLeadbitter M, Fancourt L, Pelletier P (1994). ''Blues Records 1943-1970'', London: Record Information Services, Vol. 2, pp. 468-469. ===Albums=== *''Good Times'' (1960) - Bluesville *''Mouth Harp Blues'' (1962) - Bluesville *''Further on Up the Road'' (1969) - World Pacific (billed as Shakey Jake and the All Stars) *''The Devil's Harmonica'' (1972) - [[Polydor Records|Polydor]] *''The Key Won't Fit'' (1984) - Murray Brothers{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/shakey-jake-harris-mn0001212808/discography |title=Shakey Jake Harris | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} ==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} *[[List of harmonicists]] *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://koti.mbnet.fi/wdd/shakeyjake.htm Shakey Jake Harris full discography] {{Persondata | NAME = Harris, James D. | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Harris, Shakey Jake. | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] singer, harmonicist and songwriter | DATE OF BIRTH = April 12, 1921 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Earle, Arkansas]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = March 2, 1990 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Forrest City, Arkansas]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Harris, Shakey Jake}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Arkansas]] [[Category:American blues harmonica players]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:Harmonica blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Arkansas]] [[Category:Musicians from Illinois]]
